Select Dictionaries

Source: R/utils.R
select.dict.Rd

Retrieve information and links to dictionaries (lexicons/word lists) available at osf.io/y6g5b.

Usage

select.dict(query = NULL, dir = getOption("lingmatch.dict.dir"),
  check.md5 = TRUE, mode = "wb")

Arguments

query

A character matching a dictionary name, or a set of keywords to search for in dictionary information.

dir

Path to a folder containing dictionaries, or where you want them to be saved. Will look in getOption('lingmatch.dict.dir') and '~/Dictionaries' by default.

check.md5

Logical; if TRUE (default), retrieves the MD5 checksum from OSF, and compares it with that calculated from the downloaded file to check its integrity.

mode

Passed to download.file when downloading files.

Value

A list with varying entries:

  • info: The version of osf.io/kjqb8 stored internally; a data.frame with dictionary names as row names, and information about each dictionary in columns.
    Also described at osf.io/y6g5b/wiki/dict_variables, here short (corresponding to the file name [{short}.(csv|dic)] and wiki urls [https://osf.io/y6g5b/wiki/{short}]) is set as row names and removed:

    • name: Full name of the dictionary.

    • description: Description of the dictionary, relating to its purpose and development.

    • note: Notes about processing decisions that additionally alter the original.

    • constructor: How the dictionary was constructed:

      • algorithm: Terms were selected by some automated process, potentially learned from data or other resources.

      • crowd: Several individuals rated the terms, and in aggregate those ratings translate to categories and weights.

      • mixed: Some combination of the other methods, usually in some iterative process.

      • team: One of more individuals make decisions about term inclusions, categories, and weights.

    • subject: Broad, rough subject or purpose of the dictionary:

      • emotion: Terms relate to emotions, potentially exemplifying or expressing them.

      • general: A large range of categories, aiming to capture the content of the text.

      • impression: Terms are categorized and weighted based on the impression they might give.

      • language: Terms are categorized or weighted based on their linguistic features, such as part of speech, specificity, or area of use.

      • social: Terms relate to social phenomena, such as characteristics or concerns of social entities.

    • terms: Number of unique terms across categories.

    • term_type: Format of the terms:

      • glob: Include asterisks which denote inclusion of any characters until a word boundary.

      • glob+: Glob-style asterisks with regular expressions within terms.

      • ngram: Includes any number of words as a term, separated by spaces.

      • pattern: A string of characters, potentially within or between words, or spanning words.

      • regex: Regular expressions.

      • stem: Unigrams with common endings removed.

      • unigram: Complete single words.

    • weighted: Indicates whether weights are associated with terms. This determines the file type of the dictionary: dictionaries with weights are stored as .csv, and those without are stored as .dic files.

    • regex_characters: Logical indicating whether special regular expression characters are present in any term, which might need to be escaped if the terms are used in regular expressions. Glob-type terms allow complete parens (at least one open and one closed, indicating preceding or following words), and initial and terminal asterisks. For all other terms, [](){}*.^$+?\| are counted as regex characters. These could be escaped in R with gsub('([][)(}{*.^$+?\\|])', '\\\1', terms) if terms is a character vector, and in Python with (importing re) [re.sub(r'([][(){}*.^$+?\|])', r'\\1', term) for term in terms] if terms is a list.

    • categories: Category names in the order in which they appear in the dictionary file, separated by commas.

    • ncategories: Number of categories.

    • original_max: Maximum value of the original dictionary before standardization: original values / max(original values) * 100. Dictionaries with no weights are considered to have a max of 1.

    • osf: ID of the file on OSF, translating to the file's URL: https://osf.io/osf.

    • wiki: URL of the dictionary's wiki.

    • downloaded: Path to the file if downloaded, and '' otherwise.

  • selected: A subset of info selected by query.

See also

Other Dictionary functions: download.dict(), lma_patcat(), lma_termcat(), read.dic()

Examples

# just retrieve information about available dictionaries
(dicts = select.dict()$info)
#>                                                                                            name

#> mpqa_effects                                                                                                                                                          Original terms are WordNet synsets -- standardized version replaces underscores with spaces; excludes the null category. Terms in both categories have positive and negative senses, which are not differentiated here.
#> mpqa_subjectivity                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Excludes the "anypos", "both", and "weakneg" categories.
#> mwnop                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         Original terms are WordNet Synsets  -- standardized terms has underscores replaces with spaces.
#> nrc_color                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             Original terms are WordNet synsets -- standardized terms average across senses. Standardized weights are votes for color / total votes.
#> nrc_eil                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      
#> nrc_sentiment                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 Standardized terms replace underscores with spaces, and separates synonym sets.
#> nrc_vad                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      
#> nrc_yelp              Values represent sentiment within the given category; standardized values are (positive / total reviews - .5) * 2; terms with 0 values within a category are ultimately set to 1e-6, such that zero-valued terms are those not present in the given category; converted special characters to regular equivalents, and removed terms with remaining special characters.

#> senticnet                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Original terms are ConceptNet names -- standardized terms have underscores replaces with spaces.
#> sentiwordnet                                                                                                               Original terms are WordNet Synsets -- standardized version removes the sense tag, averages scores across all senses leaving only one entry per term, and replaces underscores separating words with spaces; terms with 0 positive and negative values are omitted.
#> slangsd                                                                                                                                Converts special characters to regular equivalents, and removes those without regular equivalents; excludes terms with 0 weights and those with only 1 character after removing special characters or that were already present after standardization.
#> stopwords                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Standardized terms are lowercased; "MARKA" removed from "KONVERTIBILNA MARKA"; converts special characters to regular equivalents.
#> vader                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Converts special characters to regular equivalents, and averaged across duplicate terms.
#> whissell                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           Typographic apostrophes changed to typewriter apostrophes.

#> nrc_sentiment         National Research Council Canada - Macquarie Semantic Orientation Lexicon
#> nrc_yelp               National Research Council Canada - Yelp Word-Aspect Association Lexicons
#> sd_8k                                                       SentimentDictionaries - 8-K filings
#> sd_imdb                                                    SentimentDictionaries - IMDB reviews
#> senticnet                                                                             SenticNet
#> sentiwordnet                                                                       SentiWordNet
#> slangsd                                                              Slang Sentiment Dictionary
#> vader                                  Valence Aware Dictionary for sEntiment Reasoning (Vader)
#> wwbp_empathy_distress      World Well-Being Project - Empathetic Concerns and Personal Distress
#> wwbp_wellbeing                                            World Well-Being Project - Well-Being
#>                                                                                                                                               description
#> afinn                            Collects terms from other dictionaries, Twitter, Urban Dictionary, and Wiktionary; for sentiment analysis in microblogs.
#> anew_emotion                                                                                                     Participant-rated emotion for each word.
#> depechemood                                                                     Terms associated with user-rated emotion of news articles on rappler.com.
#> emolex                                                                          Terms associated with user-rated emotion of news articles on rappler.com.
#> emosenticnet                                                                                     Categorized SenticNet concepts by way of WordNet Affect.
#> emote                                                      Terms rated by student participants out of context in terms of emotion and meaning dimensions.
#> galc                                                                                  Terms meant to capture a broad range of affect-related experiences.
#> huliu                                                             Manually compiled; applied to reviews for opinion mining. Also called the Bing Lexicon.
#> inquirer                           General purpose dictionary for content analysis. Also called the Harvard Dictionary. Includes the Lasswell dictionary.
#> labmt                                                                                          Mturk workers's sentiment ratings of a broad set of terms.
#> loughranmcdonald                                                                         Terms meant to more accurately identify tone in financial texts.
#> lusi                                                                                   Terms relating to various emotional/cognitive states and behavior.
#> mpqa_effects                                                                                       Effect/event-related terms with associated sentiments.
#> mwnop                                                                                                               Manually rated opinion-related terms.
#> nrc_eil                                      Terms rated by CrowdFlower workers in terms of their association with a set of emotions. Also called EmoLex.
#> nrc_sentiment                                                                                                  Thesaurus-based expansion from seed terms.
#> nrc_yelp                                                                                         Terms associated with Yelp restaurant review sentiments.
#> sd_8k                                                                                                 Polarity scores learned from annotated 8-K filings.
#> sd_imdb                                                                    Polarity scores learned from annotated Internet Movie Database (IMDB) reviews.
#> senticnet                                                                          Uses WordNet Affect to rate ConceptNet concepts in terms of sentiment.
#> sentiwordnet          Classifiers trained to rate terms' positivity and negativity, with objectivity being 1 - (positive + negative); for opinion mining.
#> slangsd                                                       Uses Urban Dictionary, other sentiment dictionaries, and Twitter to assign polarity scores.
#> vader                                                 Aggregated term list rated by MTurk workers; for social media texts; includes netspeak-style terms.
#> wwbp_empathy_distress                                                                 Terms associated with the rated empathy and distress of blog posts.
#> wwbp_wellbeing                                                                                             Terms associated with a measure of well-being.
#>                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          note
#> afinn                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       Removed the special character version of "naive".
#> anew_emotion                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 
#> depechemood                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               Removes 73,942 terms that were not in common embeddings terms (osf.io/489he) and did not have a frequency over 100.
#> emolex                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               Original terms are part-of-speech tagged -- standardized version removed tags and averaged common terms.
#> emosenticnet                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Original terms are concept names -- standardized terms have underscores replaces with spaces.
#> emote                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Values averaged across number of raters with non-missing values.
#> galc                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
#> huliu                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       Removed the special character version of "naive".
#> inquirer                                                                                                                    Original terms are uppercase and have sense tags -- the standardized version lowercases them and removes sense tags. Standardized categories are renamed, and combined in some cases; https://osf.io/8ymt3 is a map between original and standardized categories.
#> labmt                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Values are original - 5 for polarity; retains only terms with adjusted ratings over |1|.
#> loughranmcdonald                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           Standardized terms are lowercased.
#> lusi                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
#> mpqa_effects                                                                                                                                                          Original terms are WordNet synsets -- standardized version replaces underscores with spaces; excludes the null category. Terms in both categories have positive and negative senses, which are not differentiated here.
#> mwnop                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         Original terms are WordNet Synsets  -- standardized terms has underscores replaces with spaces.
#> nrc_eil                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      
#> nrc_sentiment                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 Standardized terms replace underscores with spaces, and separates synonym sets.
#> nrc_yelp              Values represent sentiment within the given category; standardized values are (positive / total reviews - .5) * 2; terms with 0 values within a category are ultimately set to 1e-6, such that zero-valued terms are those not present in the given category; converted special characters to regular equivalents, and removed terms with remaining special characters.
#> sd_8k                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        
#> sd_imdb                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      
#> senticnet                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Original terms are ConceptNet names -- standardized terms have underscores replaces with spaces.
#> sentiwordnet                                                                                                               Original terms are WordNet Synsets -- standardized version removes the sense tag, averages scores across all senses leaving only one entry per term, and replaces underscores separating words with spaces; terms with 0 positive and negative values are omitted.
#> slangsd                                                                                                                                Converts special characters to regular equivalents, and removes those without regular equivalents; excludes terms with 0 weights and those with only 1 character after removing special characters or that were already present after standardization.
#> vader                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Converts special characters to regular equivalents, and averaged across duplicate terms.
#> wwbp_empathy_distress                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        
#> wwbp_wellbeing                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Removed terms with miss-encoded characters.
#>                       constructor    subject  terms term_type weighted
